article.description: Rasheed Wallace had 22 points and 13 rebounds as Portland extended  its season-high winning streak to seven games and handed Washington  its sixth  straight defeat, 105-101.

related.description: Michael Jordan, on the injured list for only the second time in his career, had arthroscopic surgery Wednesday morning.

article.headline: Surprising Wizards take Blazers down to the wire
article.linkText: Without Jordan, Wizards fall just short against Blazers
article.story:
WASHINGTON (AP) -- Not only were the Washington Wizards competitive without Michael Jordan, they played well enough to ponder whether a few late calls cost them the game. Rasheed Wallace had 22 points and 14 rebounds Wednesday night, and the Portland Trail Blazers nearly blew a 10-point fourth-quarter lead in a surprisingly close 105-101 victory over the Wizards. "Are we throwing up the white flag? I think you can see that we're not," Washington coach Doug Collins said. "I don't know how many games we're going to win, but we're not going to throw up the white flag." Ex-Jordan teammate Scottie Pippen scored 19 points, Ruben Patterson had 20, and Dale Davis had 16 points and 11 rebounds for the Trail Blazers, who have won seven straight and have a 2-0 start to their East Coast road trip. Richard Hamilton scored 31 points, and Chris Whitney had 19 points and a season-high 11 assists for the Wizards, who have lost six straight and are 1-8 since the All-Star break. But Washington played one of its best offensive games in weeks, putting on a remarkable display of coaching, teamwork and composure without Jordan -- and without either of its top two centers. The Wizards shot 56 percent through three quarters, and the game was tied at 83 going into the fourth. A 1-for-10 start to the fourth quarter dug the Wizards a 10-point hole, but they rallied to pull within two when Whitney made two free throws with 7.2 seconds remaining. Then came a vital call: Pippen lost control of the inbounds pass, but he was saved from a turnover when Courtney Alexander was called for pushing him as the ball went out of bounds. "I don't want to say anything derogatory toward the refs, but I don't think it was a foul," Alexander said. "At that point of the game, that's just a tough call to make." Pippen hit two free throws with 6.5 seconds to go to seal the victory. The Wizards didn't shoot a free throw in the second half until Whitney made a pair with 1:24 to go. Hamilton and Popeye Jones drew contact with moves to the paint in the final minute -- but no call was made. "It's not like we didn't have guys taking it to the basket," Collins said. "We just didn't get those calls." Jordan, who leads the team in scoring, assists and minutes, had surgery Wednesday morning to repair torn cartilage in his right knee. He was placed on the injured list Tuesday and is expected to miss 2-to-6 weeks. In addition, Jahidi White was sidelined with a strained left shoulder, and backup center Brendan Haywood sat out with a sore left knee. But coach Doug Collins spent the last two days designing new non-Jordan plays with clever passing angles that created layups for guards and forwards alike. No longer confined to operating around Jordan in a half-court game, Washington ran more than it has all season. The Wizards shot 74 percent and had 12 assists and 10 fast-break points in the first quarter alone. They were shooting 63 percent with 22 assists and 18 fast-break points at halftime and had a season-high 61 first-half points. The problem was at the defensive end, where the Wizards didn't have the manpower to match the front court of Pippen, Wallace and Davis. The Trail Blazers also had a season-high first-half point total, 64, and they finished with 20 offensive rebounds and a 26-6 advantage in second-chance points. "We believe that we can win ball games when we're not playing our best," Portland coach Maurice Cheeks said. "And tonight is an example." The bounces kept going the Wizards' way through three quarters. Rarely used rookie Kwame Brown, activated off the injured list to take Jordan's spot on the roster, made an eye-popping baseline move. And, just when Portland seemed to be building momentum at the end of the period, Tyronn Lue hit a running 28-foot 3-pointer at the buzzer to tie the score going into the fourth But the Wizards went in a slump for the next six minutes, giving Portland control of the game. "We knew that with Michael out, everybody had to pick the energy up," Alexander said. "We did a good job, but it's hard to have a moral victory at this point of the season."

Game notes
Collins made a last-minute shuffle and started Christian Laettner at center, the 15th starting lineup the Wizards have used this season. ... Bonzi Wells and Cheeks picked up back-to-back technical fouls for arguing with the officials late in the second quarter. ... Pippen on Jordan: "I just wish him the best. I was looking forward to playing against him, but I wasn't trying to make a whole lot of it."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
